statement.p: This example will complete the definition of polar area.

li.p: Recall the definition of the definite integral; where do the individual pieces of the definition come from?
Consider the polar region \mathcal{R} drawn below. Label the region, and develop an approximation for a small sector, \Delta \theta; call the area \Delta A_i.

ol.p: Use part (b) to develop an approximation for the area of \mathcal{R}, then convert the approximation to an integral.

li.p:
The definite integral is given by
\ds \int_a^b f(x)\, dx = \lim_{n\to\infty} \sum_{i=1}^n f(x_i)\Delta x
The central idea we're concerned about is that we are summing rectangular areas given by f(x_i)\Delta x for each x_i in the partition of [a,b]; the limit allows us to analyze what happens when the number of rectangles increases without bound.

The area A_i is given by the expression
A_i = \dfrac{1}{2}[f(\theta_{i})]^2\Delta\theta

ol.p:
Since A_i approximates one portion of the entire area, we sum and take a limit:
A \approx \sum_{i=1}^n A_i
so that
A = \ds \lim_{n\to\infty} \sum_{i=1}^n A_i
and we conclude that
A = \ds \int_a^b \dfrac{1}{2}[f(\theta)]^2\, d\theta

assemblage.title: Area in Polar Coordinates
assemblage.p:
If r = f(\theta) is a continuous polar curve, then the area contained beneath f(\theta) and between the angle \theta = a and \theta = b is given by the formula
A = \ds \int_a^b \dfrac{1}{2}[f(\theta)]^2\, d\theta

assemblage.title: Arc Length in Polar Coordinates
assemblage.p:
For polar curve r = f(\theta), if f' is continuous on [a,b], then the length of r on the interval a\leq \theta \leq b is given by
L = \ds \int_a^b \sqrt{r^2 + \lrpar{\dfrac{dr}{d\theta}}^2}\, d\theta
